q: What are the causes of scurvy?
a: Scurvy is caused by not having enough vitamin C in your diet over a long period of time. Vitamin C is mainly found in fruit and vegetables. Other factors that may increase the risk of scurvy include not consuming fresh fruits or vegetables, eating very little food, smoking, long-term dependency on drugs or alcohol, and having a poor diet while pregnant or breastfeeding.

q: What are the symptoms of scurvy?
a: Symptoms of scurvy may include feeling very tired and weak all the time, feeling irritable and sad all the time, joint, muscle, or leg pains, swollen and bleeding gums, development of red or blue spots on the skin, and easy bruising.

q: When should I see a GP regarding scurvy?
a: You should see a GP if you or your child are at risk of scurvy and experiencing symptoms such as feeling very tired and weak all the time, feeling irritable and sad all the time, having joint, muscle, or leg pain, or having wounds that reopen or are not healing well.

q: What is considered urgent advice for scurvy?
a: If you or your child are at risk of scurvy and have symptoms like easily bruising skin, swollen and bleeding gums, joint or leg swelling, high temperature or fever, yellowing of the whites of the eyes or skin, you should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: When should I seek immediate medical attention for scurvy?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E immediately if you or your child have symptoms such as a rash that does not fade when pressed against, a sudden and severe headache, a stiff neck, sensitivity to light, blurred or double vision, stroke-like symptoms, loss of consciousness or uncontrollable shaking, severe chest pain or difficulty breathing, confusion or drowsiness.

q: How is scurvy treated?
a: Scurvy is usually treated by adding vitamin C to the diet through fresh fruit and vegetables. Vitamin C supplements may also be recommended by a GP. Prompt treatment of scurvy generally leads to improvement within days and a full recovery. In some cases, a specialist referral may be necessary depending on the underlying cause of scurvy.

q: How can a vitamin C deficiency be prevented?
a: The best way to prevent a vitamin C deficiency is to have a healthy, balanced diet that includes fruits and vegetables. It's important to consult a GP or midwife before taking supplements or making diet changes during pregnancy or while breastfeeding.

a: The best way to prevent a vitamin C deficiency is to eat a healthy, balanced diet that includes plenty of fruit and vegetables. It's important to consult a GP or midwife before making any changes to your diet during pregnancy or while breastfeeding.

q: What are the best sources of vitamin C?
a: The best sources of vitamin C are fruit and vegetables.

q: Can vitamin C supplements help prevent scurvy?
a: Yes, vitamin C supplements can help prevent scurvy, especially if you have a deficiency or are at risk of scurvy.

q: Are there any risks associated with scurvy?
a: Yes, scurvy can cause serious problems and may even be life-threatening if left untreated. It's important to seek medical attention if you suspect you or your child may have scurvy.
